text: Climbing Mount Everest, also known as Sagarmatha in Nepal and Chomolungma in Tibet, is a lifelong dream for many.
K2, also recognized as Mount Godwin Austen, is the second-highest mountain on Earth.
Kangchenjunga stands majestically on the border between Nepal and India, being the third-highest peak.
Lhotse is frequently climbed by mountaineers attempting Mount Everest due to their close proximity.
The challenging ascent of Makalu requires significant technical skill and endurance.
Cho Oyu is often considered one of the 'easier' eight-thousanders for climbers.
The Dhaulagiri massif includes several peaks, with Dhaulagiri I being the highest.
Manaslu, often called the 'Mountain of the Spirit', is a prominent peak in the Nepalese Himalayas.
Nanga Parbat is a formidable peak in the Himalayas, known for its challenging routes.
Annapurna I, part of the Annapurna massif, was the first eight-thousander to be successfully climbed.
Gasherbrum I, also known as Hidden Peak, is one of the remote giants of the Karakoram.
Broad Peak, or Falchan Kangri, is another impressive mountain in the Karakoram range.
Gasherbrum II offers a less technically demanding climb compared to its neighbors.
Shishapangma is unique among the eight-thousanders for being entirely within Tibet.
Mont Blanc, known as Monte Bianco in Italy, is the highest mountain in the Alps.
Mount Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest peak, attracts thousands of trekkers annually.
The iconic Mount Fuji, or Fuji-san, is an active stratovolcano and Japan's highest peak.
Aconcagua, the highest mountain in the Americas, is located in the Andes mountain range.
Denali, formerly known as Mount McKinley, is North America's highest peak.
Mount Elbrus, a dormant volcano, is the highest peak in Russia and Europe.
